issue.title: [DOC] Updated docstrings to inform that methods accept ForecastingHorizon

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
…rizon.

<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->
I updated the docstrings of the following methods to inform that they accept `fh=ForecastingHorizon`.
```python
sktime.forecasting.base._base.BaseForecaster.fit()
sktime.forecasting.base._base.BaseForecaster.predict()
sktime.forecasting.base._base.BaseForecaster.score()
sktime.forecasting.base._sktime._SktimeForecaster._set_fh()
sktime.forecasting.base._sktime._SktimeForecaster.predict()
sktime.forecasting.base._sktime._SktimeForecaster.update_predict_single()
sktime.forecasting.base._sktime._OptionalForecastingHorizonMixin._set_fh()
sktime.forecasting.base._sktime._RequiredForecastingHorizonMixin._set_fh()
sktime.forecasting.base.adapters._pmdarima._PmdArimaAdapter.fit()
```

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?
No.
<!--
If your contribution does add a new hard dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum.
-->

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

<!-- This section is particularly useful if you have a pull request that is still in development. You can guide the reviews to focus on the parts that are ready for their comments. We suggest using bullets (indicated by * or -) and filled checkboxes [x] here -->

#### Any other comments?
<!--
Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering, convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.
-->

#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [ ] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [ ] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [ ] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.

##### For new estimators
- [ ] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.


<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->

issue.title: Forecasting multivariate time series in Sktime

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Pls, I'll like to know how to handle forecasting in multivariate time series with sktime.
Let's say I have two time series variables energy load and temperature (or even including 3rd variable, var3) at hourly intervals and I'm interested in forecasting the load demand only  for the next 48hrs.
1- Would it suffice to treat this as a univariate time series forcasting by discarding the other variables (temperature and var3)?
2- If i want to keep both variables but forecast on energy load, how would this be treated with sktime?

**Update to this question:**
**@mloning** , you responded earlier that this could be treated as a univariate time series with exogenous variables.
Pls I'll like to know how I can implement this (with **multiple exogenous variables**) in sktime by reduction to tabularized features and using ML algorithms like decision tree , KNN regression etc.
I would like to compare the result with the statistical method like SARIMAX which I read (though not yet confirmed) that sktime also interfaces with.
Thanks

body:
Hello,
in context of my semester thesis i try to use sktime for time series classification. Unfortunately i have missed the onboarding days. Would it be possible to get the documents used for tutorials and similar?

sure, material from past workshops is here: https://github.com/sktime/sktime-workshop

For the introduction, I´d recommend to watch our youtube video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wqQKFu41FIw

issue.title: Issues for the 2021 summer dev sprint

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This issue collects some good issues to work on during the 2021 summer dev sprint (#863).
Will consolidate things in the first post, but please free to discuss and suggest in reply posts.

* Refactor Theta and implement AutoTheta (https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/discussions/854)
* Implement annotation module (#838)

body:
> sure, material from past workshops is here: https://github.com/sktime/sktime-workshops
> 
> For the introduction, I´d recommend to watch our youtube video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wqQKFu41FIw

Thank you very much, I am sorry to answer that late.
Unfortunately the link to the workshop materials does not work, github raises an 404 error.
I already watched the youtube video, but I was looking for some deeper information. I am especially interested in time series classification since i am currently working on my semester thesis about condition monitoring of machine tools through analysing different kinds of data.
It would be very kind of you could offer me further information. I already did some experimental work with sktime and really liked using it. But with the tutorials and documentation given it is pretty hard work.

Best regards

>Unfortunately the link to the workshop materials does not work, github raises an 404 error

Oh, very sorry, @thepworeo - I must have cut off the last letter when I copy-pasted. Please try again.

>But with the tutorials and documentation given it is pretty hard work.

We'd appreciate any feedback on how to improve tutorials and documentation - what would you like to see, what makes it hard?

We know that it's grown a bit organically and is currently not as nice as it could be. Improving documentation and tutorials will be one of the larger topics at the summer dev days.

In case you would like to contribute yourself to improving these - having users like yourself in mind - you would be more than welcome!

Ah perfect, now the link works!
I'll work through the tutorials and workshops the next days. I will be happy to give you feedback after that as well!
My main problem are the documentation and little number of examples, but i also admit not to be a professional concerning machine learning algorithms.
Probably I will spend at least the next 3-4 weeks working with sktime and I will be happy to share my experiences and suggestions for improvement.
Probably I'll come around with some more questions anyway.

issue.title: [ENH] VAR and VECM models

labels.name: interfacing algorithms
labels.description: Interfacing existing algorithms/estimators for other packages

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
@fkiraly update: almost done, all that is missing is `predict_interval` for VECM.

---

@fkiraly's summary of the discussion:

We should interface VAR and VECM from `statsmodels`.

- [x] VAR #1083, #1491
- [x] VECM #1141, #2829

---

Have you considered porting `Vector Autoregressions (VAR)` and `Vector Error Correction Models (VECM)` from [statsmodels](https://www.statsmodels.org/dev/vector_ar.html#)? This would be a great addition. Thank you
